ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: Understanding of ancient empires, and through it, understanding of our modern world.

Firstly, the course covers a large arrange of knowledge including the life of ancient people, the political, military history of ancient empires, etc. One point worth noting is the intensive usage of primary sources, especially at the later part of the course, which really helps me to improve my ability on handling them.  The course also dives me into some sort of reflection of the modern world. For example, what will we leave for a future historian to study?
I learnt lots of new different materials that I wasnt know before, the ancient empire course is great!
Overall, I learned how to manage my workload better. My overall ability to focus improved dramatically during this class either from the zoom lessons or the assigned readings.
I learned about ancient empires in the Near East in broad detail, beginning with the Neo-Assyrian Empire and continuing until the conquests.
I greatly developed skills in critical thinking and reading primary sources.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: A great transition into learning about ancient empires.

The strength of this course is its weakness as well. This is a very intensive course that should last for a semester, which definitely brings me much knowledge and thoughts. When it's been compressed into a 10 session course, the wide variety of contents sometimes intertwined together which makes me hard to follow occasionally.
I think there are no weaknesses of this course as it was already very good.

Prof. van Bladel is one of the main strengths of the course  he's a highly engaging, enthusiastic and compassionate instructor with a clear interest in teaching; all the homework is very intentional and the daily quizzes act as a good gauge of completion; lectures are full of information but dynamic and easy-to-follow. Perhaps posting more of the PowerPoints would have assisted class prep?
I think it would be helpful to include far more visual teaching elements, but the assigned reading materials were extremely helpful towards understanding.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Definitely!

Yes and no. This course is not about a popular topic, but quite a "marginal" topic. As a result, I probably wouldn't recommend it to someone having no interest in Middle East history because they may find it boring and incomprehensible. But if it's someone who has interests or even some study in any of the topics we covered in this course, I would definitely recommend this course because I am surprised by the abundant knowledge of professor Bladel. And his course no doubt can benefit that student a lot.
Yes because it is something that would broad your understanding on ancient empires and extent your intellectual thought on them. Very interesting!

I would definitely recommend this course to another student. Though it was challenging and time consuming, this course was really interesting and enlightening. This course also helped me understand the current political tensions within the Middle East.

I would recommend this course to any student, regardless of their background. It has changed the way I approach my own studies and the way I think about the world. Prof. van Bladel energetically dispels stereotypes and lazy analyses in every lesson; we began with a broad discussion about historical methodology and continued to question modes of analysis and interpretation throughout the course; I gained a better understanding of world history at large, a necessary understanding, I think, for every student. Also, unlike many intro courses, the presentation of the material doesn't feel diluted. There's a fair bit of homework, but by the time the final came I just had to glance at my notes because the homework had prepared me so thoroughly.
Yes, to some extent, if that student were willing to accept the heavy workload.

narratives.question_text: The Canvas course site allowed me to identify and access required course materials easily.
